modules.name: Text.Parsing.Indent
modules.comments:
This module is a port of the Haskell
[__Text.Parsec.Indent__](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/indents-0.3.3/docs/Text-Parsec-Indent.html)
module from 2016-05-07.

A module to construct indentation aware parsers. Many programming
language have indentation based syntax rules e.g. python and Haskell.
This module exports combinators to create such parsers.

The input source can be thought of as a list of tokens. Abstractly
each token occurs at a line and a column and has a width. The column
number of a token measures is indentation. If t1 and t2 are two tokens
then we say that indentation of t1 is more than t2 if the column
number of occurrence of t1 is greater than that of t2.

Currently this module supports two kind of indentation based syntactic
structures which we now describe:

- **Block**

  A block of indentation /c/ is a sequence of tokens with
  indentation at least /c/.  Examples for a block is a where clause of
  Haskell with no explicit braces.

- **Line fold**

  A line fold starting at line /l/ and indentation /c/ is a
  sequence of tokens that start at line /l/ and possibly continue to
  subsequent lines as long as the indentation is greater than /c/. Such
  a sequence of lines need to be /folded/ to a single line. An example
  is MIME headers. Line folding based binding separation is used in
  Haskell as well.

declarations.comments:
Indentation sensitive parser type. Usually @ m @ will
be @ Identity @ as with any @ ParserT @
declarations.title: IndentParser

declarations.comments: Run the result of an indentation sensitive parse
declarations.title: runIndent

declarations.comments:
`withBlock f a p` parses `a`
followed by an indented block of `p`
combining them with `f`.
declarations.title: withBlock

declarations.comments: Like 'withBlock', but throws away initial parse result
declarations.title: withBlock'

declarations.comments: Parses a block of lines at the same indentation level , empty Blocks allowed
declarations.title: block

declarations.comments: Parses a block of lines at the same indentation level
declarations.title: block1

declarations.comments: Parses only when indented past the level of the reference
declarations.title: indented

declarations.comments: Same as `indented`, but does not change internal state
declarations.title: indented'

declarations.comments: Parses only on the same line as the reference
declarations.title: sameLine

declarations.comments: Parses only when indented past the level of the reference or on the same line
declarations.title: sameOrIndented

declarations.comments: Ensures the current indentation level matches that of the reference
declarations.title: checkIndent

declarations.comments: Parses using the current location for indentation reference
declarations.title: withPos

declarations.comments: `<+/>` is to indentation sensitive parsers what `ap` is to monads
declarations.title: indentAp

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but doesn't apply the function to the parsed value
declarations.title: indentNoAp

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but applies the second parser many times
declarations.title: indentMany

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but applies the second parser optionally using the `Optional` datatype
declarations.title: indentOp

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding brackets
declarations.title: indentBrackets

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding angle brackets
declarations.title: indentAngles

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding braces
declarations.title: indentBraces

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding parentheses
declarations.title: indentParens

declarations.comments: Data type used to optional parsing
declarations.title: Optional

declarations.comments: A parsing error, consisting of a message and position information.
declarations.title: ParseError

declarations.comments: Contains the remaining input and current position.
declarations.title: ParseState

children.comments:
The alternative `Alt` instance provides the `alt` combinator `<|>`.

The expression `p_left <|> p_right` will first try the `p_left` parser and if that fails
__and consumes no input__ then it will try the `p_right` parser.

While we are parsing down the `p_left` branch we may reach a point where
we know this is the correct branch, but we cannot parse further. At
that point we want to fail the entire parse instead of trying the `p_right`
branch.

For example, consider this `fileParser` which can parse either an HTML
file that begins with `<html>` or a shell script file that begins with `#!`.

```
fileParser =
  string "<html>" *> parseTheRestOfTheHtml
  <|>
  string "#!" *> parseTheRestOfTheScript
```

If we read a file from disk and run this `fileParser` on it and the
`string "<html>"` parser succeeds, then we know that the first branch
is the correct branch, so we want to commit to the first branch. 
Even if the `parseTheRestOfTheHtml` parser fails
we don’t want to try the second branch.

To control the point at which we commit to the `p_left` branch
use the `try` combinator and the `lookAhead` combinator and
the `consume` function.

The `alt` combinator works this way because it gives us good localized
error messages while also allowing an efficient implementation. See
[*Parsec: Direct Style Monadic Parser Combinators For The Real World*](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/parsec-paper-letter.pdf)
section __2.3 Backtracking__.
children.title: altParserT

declarations.comments:
The Parser monad transformer.

The first type argument is the stream type. Typically, this is either `String`,
or some sort of token stream.
declarations.title: ParserT

declarations.comments: The `Parser` monad is a synonym for the parser monad transformer applied to the `Identity` monad.
declarations.title: Parser

declarations.comments: Apply a parser, keeping only the parsed result.
declarations.title: runParser

declarations.comments: Apply a parser, keeping only the parsed result.
declarations.title: runParserT

declarations.comments: Change the underlying monad action and data type in a ParserT monad action.
declarations.title: mapParserT

declarations.comments:
Set the consumed flag.

Setting the consumed flag means that we're committed to this parsing branch
of an alternative (`<|>`), so that if this branch fails then we want to
fail the entire parse instead of trying the other alternative.
declarations.title: consume

declarations.comments: Returns the current position in the stream.
declarations.title: position

declarations.comments: Fail with a message.
declarations.title: fail

declarations.comments: Fail with a message and a position.
declarations.title: failWithPosition

declarations.comments:
Contextualize parsing failures inside a region. If a parsing failure
occurs, then the `ParseError` will be transformed by each containing
`region` as the parser backs out the call stack.
declarations.title: region

declarations.comments:
Perform an Applicative action `n` times, and accumulate all the results.

``` purescript
> replicateA 5 (randomInt 1 10) :: Effect (Array Int)
[1,3,2,7,5]
```
declarations.title: replicateA

declarations.comments:
Perform an `Apply` action `n` times (at least once, so values `n` less
than 1 will be treated as 1), and accumulate the results.

``` purescript
> replicate1A 2 (randomInt 1 10) :: Effect (NEL.NonEmptyList Int)
(NonEmptyList (NonEmpty 8 (2 : Nil)))
> replicate1A 0 (randomInt 1 10) :: Effect (NEL.NonEmptyList Int)
(NonEmptyList (NonEmpty 4 Nil))
```
declarations.title: replicate1A

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Combinators
modules.comments:
## Combinators in other packages

Many variations of well-known monadic and applicative combinators used for parsing are
defined in other PureScript packages. It’s awkward to re-export
them because their names overlap so much, so we list them here.

### Data.Array
* [Data.Array.many](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-arrays/docs/Data.Array#v:many)
* [Data.Array.some](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-arrays/docs/Data.Array#v:some)

### Data.Array.NonEmpty
* [Data.Array.NonEmpty.some](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-arrays/docs/Data.Array.NonEmpty#v:some)

### Data.List
* [Data.List.many](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List#v:many)
* [Data.List.some](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List#v:some)
* [Data.List.someRec](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List#v:someRec)
* [Data.List.manyRec](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List#v:manyRec)

### Data.List.NonEmpty
* See the __many1__ combinator below.

### Data.List.Lazy
* [Data.List.Lazy.many](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List.Lazy#v:many)
* [Data.List.Lazy.some](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List.Lazy#v:some)
* [Data.List.Lazy.replicateM](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List.Lazy#v:replicateM)

## Combinators in this package

A parser combinator is a function which takes some
parsers as arguments and returns a new parser.

The __many__ combinator applied to parser `p :: Parser s a` will return
a parser `many p :: Parser s (Array a)` which will repeat the
parser `p` as many times as possible. If `p` never consumes input when it
fails then `many p` will always succeed
but may return an empty array.

The __replicateA n__ combinator applied to parser `p :: Parser s a` will
return a parser `replicateA n p :: Parser s (Array a)` which will
repeat parser `p` exactly `n` times. `replicateA n p` will only succeed
if it can match parser `p` exactly `n` consecutive times.

declarations.comments: Flipped `(<?>)`.
declarations.title: asErrorMessage

declarations.comments:
Wrap a parser with opening and closing markers.

For example:

```purescript
parens = between (string "(") (string ")")
```
declarations.title: between

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator.

For example:

```purescript
chainr digit (string "+" $> add) 0
```
declarations.title: chainl

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: chainl1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator, requiring at least one match.

Stack-safe version of `chainl1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: chainl1Rec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator.

Stack-safe version of `chainl` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: chainlRec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator.

For example:

```purescript
chainr digit (string "+" $> add) 0
```
declarations.title: chainr

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: chainr1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator, requiring at least one match.

Stack-safe version of `chainr1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: chainr1Rec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator.

Stack-safe version of `chainr` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: chainrRec

declarations.comments: Parse one of a set of alternatives.
declarations.title: choice

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator.
declarations.title: endBy

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: endBy1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.

Stack-safe version of `endBy1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: endBy1Rec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator.

Stack-safe version of `endBy` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: endByRec

declarations.comments: Parse a phrase, without modifying the consumed state or stream position.
declarations.title: lookAhead

declarations.comments: Match one or more times.
declarations.title: many1

declarations.comments:
Match one or more times.

Stack-safe version of `many1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: many1Rec

declarations.comments: Parse at least one phrase until the terminator phrase matches.
declarations.title: many1Till

declarations.comments:
Parse at least one phrase until the terminator phrase matches.

Stack-safe version of `many1Till` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: many1TillRec

declarations.comments:
Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches, requiring at least one match.
Returns the list of phrases and the terminator phrase.

Stack-safe version of `many1Till_` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: many1TillRec_

declarations.comments:
Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches, requiring at least one match.
Returns the list of phrases and the terminator phrase.
declarations.title: many1Till_

declarations.comments: Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches.
declarations.title: manyTill

declarations.comments:
Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches.

Stack-safe version of `manyTill` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: manyTillRec

declarations.comments:
Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches.
Returns the list of phrases and the terminator phrase.

Stack-safe version of `manyTill_` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: manyTillRec_

declarations.comments:
Parse many phrases until the terminator phrase matches.
Returns the list of phrases and the terminator phrase.

## Non-greedy repetition

Use the __manyTill_ __ combinator
to do non-greedy repetition of a pattern `p`, like we would in Regex
by writing `p*?`.
To repeat pattern `p` non-greedily, write
`manyTill_ p q` where `q` is the entire rest of the parser.

For example, this parse fails because `many` repeats the pattern `letter`
greedily.

```
runParser "aab" do
  a <- many letter
  b <- char 'b'
  pure (Tuple a b)
```
```
(ParseError "Expected 'b'" (Position { line: 1, column: 4 }))
```

To repeat pattern `letter` non-greedily, use `manyTill_`.

```
runParser "aab" do
  Tuple a b <- manyTill_ letter do
    char 'b'
  pure (Tuple a b)
```
```
(Tuple ('a' : 'a' : Nil) 'b')
```
declarations.title: manyTill_

declarations.comments:
Fail if the parser succeeds.

Will never consume input.
declarations.title: notFollowedBy

declarations.comments: Provide a default result in the case where a parser fails without consuming input.
declarations.title: option

declarations.comments: pure `Nothing` in the case where a parser fails without consuming input.
declarations.title: optionMaybe

declarations.comments:
Optionally parse something, failing quietly.

To optionally parse `p` and never fail: `optional (try p)`.
declarations.title: optional

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a separator.

For example:

```purescript
digit `sepBy` string ","
```
declarations.title: sepBy

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: sepBy1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a separator, requiring at least one match.

Stack-safe version of `sepBy1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: sepBy1Rec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a separator.

Stack-safe version of `sepBy` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: sepByRec

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator.
declarations.title: sepEndBy

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: sepEndBy1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.

Stack-safe version of `sepEndBy1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: sepEndBy1Rec

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator.

Stack-safe version of `sepEndBy` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: sepEndByRec

declarations.comments: Skip many instances of a phrase.
declarations.title: skipMany

declarations.comments: Skip at least one instance of a phrase.
declarations.title: skipMany1

declarations.comments:
Skip at least one instance of a phrase.

Stack-safe version of `skipMany1` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: skipMany1Rec

declarations.comments:
Skip many instances of a phrase.

Stack-safe version of `skipMany` at the expense of a `MonadRec` constraint.
declarations.title: skipManyRec

declarations.comments:
If the parser fails then backtrack the input stream to the unconsumed state.

One use for this combinator is to ensure that the right parser of an
alternative will always be tried when the left parser fails.
```
>>> runParser "ac" ((char 'a' *> char 'b') <|> (char 'a' *> char 'c'))
Left (ParseError "Expected 'b'" (Position { line: 1, column: 2 }))
```

```
>>> runParser "ac" (try (char 'a' *> char 'b') <|> (char 'a' *> char 'c'))
Right 'c'
```
declarations.title: try

declarations.comments:
If the parser fails then backtrack the input stream to the unconsumed state.

Like `try`, but will relocate the error to the `try` point.

```
>>> runParser "ac" (try (char 'a' *> char 'b'))
Left (ParseError "Expected 'b'" (Position { line: 1, column: 2 }))
```

```
>>> runParser "ac" (tryRethrow (char 'a' *> char 'b'))
Left (ParseError "Expected 'b'" (Position { line: 1, column: 1 }))
```
declarations.title: tryRethrow

declarations.comments: Provide an error message in the case of failure.
declarations.title: withErrorMessage

declarations.comments:
Provide an error message in the case of failure, but lazily. This is handy
in cases where constructing the error message is expensive, so it's
preferable to defer it until an error actually happens.

```purs
parseBang :: Parser Char
parseBang = char '!' <~?> \_ -> "Expected a bang"
```
declarations.title: withLazyErrorMessage

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Expr
modules.comments:
This module is a port of the Haskell
[__Text.Parsec.Expr__](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/parsec/docs/Text-Parsec-Expr.html)
module.

declarations.comments:
Build a parser from an `OperatorTable`.

For example:

```purescript
buildExprParser [ [ Infix (string "/" $> div) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "*" $> mul) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "-" $> sub) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "+" $> add) AssocRight ]
                ] digit
```
declarations.title: buildExprParser

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Language
modules.comments:
This module is a port of the Haskell
[__Text.Parsec.Language__](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/parsec/docs/Text-Parsec-Language.html)
module.

declarations.comments: The language definition for the Haskell language.
declarations.title: haskellDef

declarations.comments: A lexer for the haskell language.
declarations.title: haskell

declarations.comments:
This is the most minimal token definition. It is recommended to use
this definition as the basis for other definitions. `emptyDef` has
no reserved names or operators, is case sensitive and doesn't accept
comments, identifiers or operators.
declarations.title: emptyDef

declarations.comments:
This is a minimal token definition for Haskell style languages. It
defines the style of comments, valid identifiers and case
sensitivity. It does not define any reserved words or operators.
declarations.title: haskellStyle

declarations.comments:
This is a minimal token definition for Java style languages. It
defines the style of comments, valid identifiers and case
sensitivity. It does not define any reserved words or operators.
declarations.title: javaStyle

declarations.comments:
`Position` represents the position of the parser in the input.

- `line` is the current line in the input
- `column` is the column of the next character in the current line that will be parsed
declarations.title: Position

declarations.comments: The `Position` before any input has been parsed.
declarations.title: initialPos

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.String
modules.comments:
Primitive parsers for working with an input stream of type `String`.

All of these primitive parsers will consume their input when they succeed.

All of these primitive parsers will consume no input when they
fail.

The behavior of these primitive parsers is based on the behavior of the
`Data.String` module in the __strings__ package.
In most JavaScript runtime environments, the `String`
is little-endian [UTF-16](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-16).

The primitive parsers which return `Char` will only succeed when the character
being parsed is a code point in the
[Basic Multilingual Plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(Unicode)#Basic_Multilingual_Plane)
(the “BMP”). These parsers can be convenient because of the good support
that PureScript has for writing `Char` literals like `'あ'`, `'β'`, `'C'`.

The other primitive parsers, which return `CodePoint` and `String` types,
can parse the full Unicode character set. All of the primitive parsers
in this module can be used together.

declarations.comments: Match the specified string.
declarations.title: string

declarations.comments: Match “end-of-file,” the end of the input stream.
declarations.title: eof

declarations.comments: Match the entire rest of the input stream. Always succeeds.
declarations.title: rest

declarations.comments:
Match any BMP `Char`.
Parser will fail if the character is not in the Basic Multilingual Plane.
declarations.title: anyChar

declarations.comments:
Match any Unicode character.
Always succeeds.
declarations.title: anyCodePoint

declarations.comments: Match a BMP `Char` satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: satisfy

declarations.comments: Match a Unicode character satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: satisfyCodePoint

declarations.comments: Match the specified BMP `Char`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments: Match a `String` exactly *N* characters long.
declarations.title: takeN

declarations.comments:
Match zero or more whitespace characters satisfying
`Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`. Always succeeds.
declarations.title: whiteSpace

declarations.comments: Skip whitespace characters and throw them away. Always succeeds.
declarations.title: skipSpaces

declarations.comments: Match one of the BMP `Char`s in the array.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Match one of the Unicode characters in the array.
declarations.title: oneOfCodePoints

declarations.comments: Match any BMP `Char` not in the array.
declarations.title: noneOf

declarations.comments: Match any Unicode character not in the array.
declarations.title: noneOfCodePoints

declarations.comments:
Combinator which returns both the result of a parse and the slice of
the input that was consumed while it was being parsed.

Because `String`s are not `Char` arrays in PureScript, `many` and `some`
on `Char` parsers need to
be used with `Data.String.CodeUnits.fromCharArray` to
construct a `String`.

```
fromCharArray <$> Data.Array.many (char 'x')
```

It’s more efficient to achieve the same result by using this `match` combinator
instead of `fromCharArray`.

```
fst <$> match (Combinators.skipMany (char 'x'))
```
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Match zero or more whitespace characters satisfying
`Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`. Always succeeds.
declarations.title: whiteSpace

declarations.comments: Skip whitespace characters and throw them away. Always succeeds.
declarations.title: skipSpaces

declarations.comments: Match one of the Unicode characters in the array.
declarations.title: oneOfCodePoints

declarations.comments: Match one of the BMP `Char`s in the array.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Match any Unicode character not in the array.
declarations.title: noneOfCodePoints

declarations.comments: Match any BMP `Char` not in the array.
declarations.title: noneOf

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.String.Basic
modules.comments:
Basic `String` parsers derived from primitive `String` parsers.

Note: In the future, the
__noneOf__, __noneOfCodePoints__, __oneOf__, __oneOfCodePoints__, __skipSpaces__, __whiteSpace__
should be moved into this module and removed from the
__Text.Parsing.Parser.String__ module, because they are not primitive parsers.

declarations.comments: Parse a digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isDecDigit`.
declarations.title: digit

declarations.comments: Parse a hex digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isHexDigit`.
declarations.title: hexDigit

declarations.comments: Parse an octal digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isOctDigit`.
declarations.title: octDigit

declarations.comments: Parse an alphabetical character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlpha`.
declarations.title: letter

declarations.comments: Parse a space character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`.
declarations.title: space

declarations.comments: Parse a lowercase letter.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isLower`.
declarations.title: lower

declarations.comments: Parse an uppercase letter.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isUpper`.
declarations.title: upper

declarations.comments:
Parse an alphabetical or numerical character.
Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlphaNum`.
declarations.title: alphaNum

declarations.comments:
Parser based on the __Data.Int.fromString__ function.

This should be the inverse of `show :: String -> Int`.

Examples of strings which can be parsed by this parser:
* `"3"`
* `"-3"`
* `"+300"`
declarations.title: intDecimal

declarations.comments:
Parser based on the __Data.Number.fromString__ function.

This should be the inverse of `show :: String -> Number`.

Examples of strings which can be parsed by this parser:
* `"3"`
* `"3.0"`
* `"0.3"`
* `"-0.3"`
* `"+0.3"`
* `"-3e-1"`
* `"-3.0E-1.0"`
* `"NaN"`
* `"-Infinity"`
declarations.title: number

declarations.comments: Parse an uppercase letter.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isUpper`.
declarations.title: upper

declarations.comments: Parse a space character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`.
declarations.title: space

declarations.comments: Parse an octal digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isOctDigit`.
declarations.title: octDigit

declarations.comments: Parse an alphabetical character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlpha`.
declarations.title: letter

declarations.comments: Parse a hex digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isHexDigit`.
declarations.title: hexDigit

declarations.comments: Parse a digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isDecDigit`.
declarations.title: digit

declarations.comments:
Parse an alphabetical or numerical character.
Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlphaNum`.
declarations.title: alphaNum

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Token
modules.comments:
Primitive parsers for an input stream of type
`(`[__List__](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-lists/docs/Data.List.Types#t:List) `a)`
for working with streams of tokens.

This module is a port of the Haskell
[__Text.Parsec.Token__](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/parsec/docs/Text-Parsec-Token.html)
module.

declarations.comments: A parser which returns the first token in the stream.
declarations.title: token

declarations.comments: A parser which matches any token satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Match the specified token at the head of the stream.
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments: Match the “end-of-file,” the end of the input stream.
declarations.title: eof

declarations.comments:
The `GenLanguageDef` type is a record that contains all parameterizable
features of the "Text.Parsec.Token" module. The module `Text.Parsec.Language`
contains some default definitions.
declarations.title: GenLanguageDef

declarations.comments:
The type of the record that holds lexical parsers that work on
`s` streams over a monad `m`.
declarations.title: GenTokenParser

declarations.comments:
The expression `makeTokenParser language` creates a `GenTokenParser`
record that contains lexical parsers that are
defined using the definitions in the `language` record.

The use of this function is quite stylized - one imports the
appropiate language definition and selects the lexical parsers that
are needed from the resulting `GenTokenParser`.

```purescript
module Main where

import Text.Parsing.Parser.Language (haskellDef)
import Text.Parsing.Parser.Token (makeTokenParser)

-- The parser
expr = parens expr
   <|> identifier
   <|> ...


-- The lexer
tokenParser = makeTokenParser haskellDef
parens      = tokenParser.parens
braces      = tokenParser.braces
identifier  = tokenParser.identifier
reserved    = tokenParser.reserved
...
```
declarations.title: makeTokenParser
